content.description:
Buster climbs the crack twenty feet left of the right side of the wall to a slab split by a thin crack/seam.

Right side of the wall. Twenty feet left of the right end of the wall. Begin below a large triangular block that protrudes from the wall at mid-height.
Standard rack.

climbs.name: Chopper Malone
climbs.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence Steve Smaridge, Grame Taylor (1992)

content.description:
The large crack on the far left side of the crag, leads up into a V slot.

Single Rack

climbs.name: Clean Streak
climbs.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence Steve Smaridge, Grame Taylor (1992)

content.description:
Follow up the cracks to the right of "Chopper Malone" that lead into a wider slot.

Single rack.

This route is not in the 2012 version of the Squamish Select guide book, but is found as an update release on Quickdraw Publications' website in 2018. 

This line starts out on the slab to the right of Pee Wee. Follow the furthest right crack up to the ledge and finish up the same line as for Pee Wee.

To climber's right of Buster/Pee Wee. Rightmost crack on the slabby section. 
Similar to Pee Wee - details unknown

LeRoy begins in a finger crack at the right side of the wall. Pull onto the face via the finger crack and a good hold created by the top of a large flake on the right. Continue up the face past a horizontal and a bolt that protects a face move onto a smooth sloping ledge. From the ledge climb onto a block on the left and stem up to another bolt that protects the steep, thinly featured slab and the final moves to the top.


Right side of the Call It a Day Wall. Ten feet right of the start of Buster & Pee Wee. Begin in a left leaning finger crack.


LeRoy is a mixed route containing two bolts which can to supplemented with a yellow Alien or similar sized cam, small HB Offset or similar sized nut, a 0.75, #1 or #2 Camalot, and a couple quickdraws.

Start in the crack as for Buster, but traverse under the large triangular block and climb the blocky upper face and crack.

Right side of the wall. Twenty feet left of the right edge of the wall. Start below a large triangular block protruding from the wall at mid-height.
Standard Rack

climbs.name: Ramp-o-Rama
climbs.fa: Pam Cook, Lynn Gillespie, Chris Lawrence, Steve Smaridge, Graeme Taylor, 1992.

content.description:
Climb any of three short cracks in the middle of the wall up to the horizontal break.  Aim towards the base of the right-leaning ramp feature, and climb up that to the top.

 

Middle of Call It a Day cliff
Protection is somewhat sparse and wandering, depending on what you choose to climb.

Start by climbing Clean Streak, then cut right to the finger crack between it and Ramp-O-Rama.

Shares anchor with Clean Streak
Small low angled crag south of Funarama. Many well featured easy climbs.
